dialogues.text: Uh, well I ran into - people. There's some people from - the MoD over and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Penny Grayling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - no, another - gang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Wow. I didn't know you had so many delegations in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British are coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I need to just check out a couple of things ... this seems like a good point to break things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er - no problem. They start to get up, not quite sure what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon and Toby walk out into a larger office. They find a couple of seats left out for people waiting and sit down. Various staffers come and go, picking up papers and files, saying hi, looking knackered, all drinking either diet cokes or coffees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby -- I don't want to read you the riot act here but I am going to have to read some extracts from the riot act. Like Section 1 paragraph 1 clause 1. Don't leave your boss twisting in the wind and then burst in late smelling like a pissed seaside donkey. (special needs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `The British are coming'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feels he's taken enough now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I turned up late to the meeting Simon. I'm sorry. But it's not like I threw up in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're right. I should be thanking you for not throwing up. Well done. You're a star. You didn't wet yourself, you're in the right city, you didn't say anything overtly racist, you didn't pull your dick out and start plucking it and shouting 'willy banjo'. No I'm being unfair, you got so much right. Without actually being there for the beginning of one of the biggest meetings of my career. You're a legend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncomfortable beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was just - the first bit was it? We're going back in do you ...think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd barely said hello. I've had muggings that have lasted longer than that. We really only spoke about flammable cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza comes out, passes by. Toby mouths `shit' to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at a list on her desk, then to a staffer) Are these all requests to get on the committee? What's going on? Did someone post an invite on Facebook? I'm drowning in Senators. It's Senator soup here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're uncomfy with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby gets up for a private word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re last night) You feeling okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm feeling fine. Why were you late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...you know...you didn't wake me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looked so sweet. I thought you knew what you were doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was asleep, of course I didn't. That's how people walk out of windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ((hand over phone, calls over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Liza, I've got another call about the Committee from Senator Crudden's office, he wants in too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on here? Fuck. Why's this my problem? Toby you sure you didn't do bad? You didn't mention the committee to anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nada. Nada.. Bad-da. Nada-bada bing-bong ding-dang-dong. (beat, she looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what I'm saying anymore I think I really am still quite drunk. Chad is passing. As Liza turns away Toby's face does a spasm of regret at his brazen lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is so hot for your paper. I'm running off another ten copies. It's spreading like a virus, Liza. You're in hot water. You're lobsterising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's by degrees. Wafting. Bisque. I smell lobster. Can you smell lobster, Toby? Simon calls Toby back over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Toby goes back to Simon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how far would you go with Linton, you freaky little stalker? Downtown? Or all the way up Brokeback Mountain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is arriving into a meeting room set up with water etc with a young man who looks like an intern, A.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you today? Beat the traffic? Malcolm looking around, as if things aren't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah. Hunky dory. Can I get a coffee? He gives AJ his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't take coat then eventually does and just puts it on a chair, not the coat stand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, if we get started, I'll get my assistant to bring us some refreshments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your assistant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting, picking up a file in the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. So, Item. We need to have a conversation about the mood of the British Parliament. Any bumps in the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry son, am I - is this it? No offence, but shouldn't you be at school with your head down a toilet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first point there, the offence. I'm afraid I'm gonna have to take it. Your second point. I'm 22. But - item - It's my birthday in nine days, so if it would be more comfortable we could... wait...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get sarcastic with me son. (starts dialling) We burnt this tight-arsed city to the ground in 1814 and I'm all for doing it again. Starting with you, you frat fuck. You get sarcastic with me again and I will stuff so much cotton wool dowm your fucking throat it'll come out of your arse like the wee tail on a playboy bunny. Okay? I thought...I was led to believe I was attending the war committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Assistant Secretary of State Linton Barwick wanted me to brief you on the work of the Future Planning Committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want the bullshit son, I want the bull. No one sidelines me. I'm away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm gets up, grabs his coat. An even younger guy wheels in a coffee trolley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here we go - the fucking Vice President has also graced us with his presence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm runs out, on the phone. Malcolm runs out of the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDY power walking/jogging on the phone to MALCOLM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the fucking war committee meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's going to the war committee I thought you knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was going to the war committee? Tell me where the fuck it's happening!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the 7th floor in room 712. (Beat) Oh Malcolm, do you like how I'm telling you what's going on where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let me tell you what's going on where you are sweet heart, a certain vinegar faced maniplulative cowbag is about to find that she's out of a fucking job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDY hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon and Toby are looking through magazines and papers. Karen is exiting her office with an entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she comes - shit - look like we're meeting, look like we're having a meeting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she passes, re magazine) ... and if you look ... at the line they take in Newsweek - that's very much ... another narrative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you at the committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like he's busy) Yeah, yeah sure, see you in a mo. Just finishing off some stuff. (to Toby loud) Okay, we're all done there. Let's roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby looks at him. As they get up and follow her at speed, tripping to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) I don't think you can say that anymore here. They don't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. Follow them. Don't lose them. Lets rock.

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: They follow Karen around a corner and she disappears into a set of doors, they follow her through, but it is the vestibule before a toilet door. Karen looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you joining me or shall I see you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you there. I don't need to ... do any of the things you need to go in there to do, so I'll just see you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen goes into the toilet. Simon and Toby head off looking sheepish. As they head out of the vestibule. There is a gaggle of Karen hangers-on. Chad-type staffers looking to get in with Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linton is with Adriano, quietly horrified by all these people. General Miller passes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (For Miller's benefit) We seem to be overrun with insurgents here, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm in seat 204, row W. Will I be able to see the big screen from there? Oh, and can I get one of those big pointy foam hands with `Go, Monster Trucks!' written on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The general is on rare form, very rare form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby spots his hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is. General George Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (And...?) Right, yep. There he is.

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: But the room is rapidly filling with bodies and din. More and more people are turning up. Toby's view of Miller is obscured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the second time in 24 hours I've had a partially obscured view of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linton calls the over-stuffed, standing-room-only room to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, due to the fact that seemingly everyone in the world who owns a suit has turned up for this meeting, we'll be relocating to a bigger room. Room 720. So, if you will be so kind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee members file out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is legging it down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee members file in. Miller goes close up to Linton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you know -- Karen and I did not appreciate having to sneak around like Mulder and Scully trying to find out about this committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're both here now. John and Yoko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I need to talk, mano-a-mano, cocks on the block, about how things are operating around here at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linton not fazed by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. How about 12:30 tomorrow, my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Miller takes his seat. Linton turns on Adriano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea how they all heard sir. There must have been a leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Miller is sitting next to Karen. They're watching Linton having angry words with Adriano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Adriano. Poor fuck. He looks like he's with his Daddy: "Sorry, Bob, you're adopted. From a couple with hereditary heart defects."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And your mother only ever kept your baby clothes for the purposes of voodoo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is sitting with Toby, marvelling at the numbers of people cramming into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm room meat again. This is a massive abattoir of room meat. Stay outside Tobes, I need a guy on the outside. Make friends with Chad, that boy from The Shining. He knows stuff. Pump him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. I want to stay in here with Miller. Don't make me pump Chad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm making you pump Chad. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be easy peasy lemon squeezy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it won't. It'll be difficult difficult lemon difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby reluctantly leaves, trying to grab another peek at Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm running like a madman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is finally assembled. The room has thirty or so people in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, welcome to this, somewhat engorged session of the Future Planning Committee. You can all see an agenda? People are looking at their agendas, low-level chatter, pouring of water, etc. - a general pre-meeting feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant Secretary -- here on point 6, it feels like there's an assumption that we'll be invading. Should we talk about the practical? I mean this is the war committee after all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Future Planning Committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unofficially it's known as the war committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, unofficially we can call anything whatever we like. (he holds up a water glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unofficially, this is a shoe. But it's not a shoe, Karen, it's a glass of water, and this is the Future Planning Committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is running down the corridor. He runs into Room 712. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch! 73   INT. BIG COMMITTEE ROOM. DAY. Karen is talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what I'm asking is has a decision been reached in principle to advocate invasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's way off agenda Karen. Although it would seem a general consensus may be forming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I noted with interest the recent comments of our colleague Simon Foster in that regard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is texting under the desk and not really paying full attention. He hears his name, looks up, waves to the group. He doesn't clock Karen's intense look that says `You are going to rebut that, aren't you?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps Mr. Foster would have something to say about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) I'm just...watching with interest. IN Britain we have a saying for complicated situations such as this, which is that it's (he can't believe he's going to say this) `Difficult, difficult, lemon, difficult.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to his text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I say it seems a consensus is forming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) That's just ridiculous. You have no basis for saying that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen, please, calm down. We don't want you to have another hemorrhage. Item One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 It's lunchtime. Lots of staffers have left their desks. A few are eating sandwiches at their desks, or reading a newspaper during lunch. Chad is emailing, reading, multi- tasking, from a corner of desk near Linton's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - do you want to go out and get some lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Lunchtime is work time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what an incredibly depressing motto. You see you're playing into the hands of the French saying that. Toby mooches around, peers in Linton's office. He spots a couple of A4 sheets of paper that have been printed out with `Climb the mountain of conflict!' across them as an encouraging slogan on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah work hours are too valuable - for networking. You gotta get in at like 6 work till 8.30 Then start making those connections baby. (he clicks his fingers rapidly, annoyingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emails and admin at lunch. See if you can play some strategic racquetball through the pm. Then in the six till midnight slot chow down on some serious policy work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And what - friends, family, novels, sexual inter-course you're going to save those for your thirties and forties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm arrives at the committee just as people are spilling out. He's pissed off. Follows Linton into bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you fucking me about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Tucker, isn't it? Hello again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might pull this kind of stunt on some young wank fresh up from Oklahoma, happy to be getting his hookers paid for by tobacco lobbyists, but not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just had a briefing from a 9-year- old finalist in Americas got talent. I think he may have been a ventriloquist. Or possibly the fucking dummie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AJ? He is one of my top guys. Stanton College Prep, Harvard...he's smart and he's great at his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fucking briefing notes were written in Alphabetti Spaghetti. When I left I nearly tripped over his umbilical cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if it troubles you that our people achieve excellence at a young age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is emerging. Linton takes Malcolm to one side, out of Simon's earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, your prime minister informs me that he's tasked you with collating some fresh British intel for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, apparently your fucking master race of gifted toddlers can't quit get the job done in between breast feeds and playing with their power rangers. So yeah, we're getting some actual grown-ups to bail you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon gets closer. Linton moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simon) Minister, thank you so much for your support and your recent "Climb the mountain of conflict" comment - great. We're going to run with that, it has great repeatability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks very much, but...it's all a bit complex really, in terms of my... Linton pulls away, starts walking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early days, my friend. All roads lead to Munich. He smiles and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck does that mean? `All roads lead to Munich'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it just means...I guess, I don't know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `All roads lead to Munich'? Malcolm is pissed off, looks around. He is not the centre of attention. He's feeling cut out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on let's go, get back to the hotel, nick as many coat hangers as you can. We're off back to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, Toby, and Simon are heading towards their car. They see the Washington Monument in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you pull it out, America deflates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mock that! The closest you'll come to getting one of those is buying a Toblerone. (Looks at Blackberry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark Hadley's dad's died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Should we send Mark a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I'll send him a ouija board so they can keep in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are we getting back to? Apart from a nice cup of tea and some knife crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constituency surgery in Northampton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, meeting my constituents. It's like being Simon Cowell, but without the ability to say, `Fuck off, you're mental.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOBY and SIMON are with Simon's constituency agent, ROZ, she's ushering them into the small, damp little constituency office. ROZ's arm is in a sling (Jo Scanlon's arm actually is in a sling) and she has difficulty opening the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simon) Sorry, could you...? You just need to kick the bottom quite hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon kicks the bottom of the door to unstick it. Roz opens the door. There are a few constituents waiting to see Simon, he nods a hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Roz has gone ahead, this is to Toby) Look at them. They all have that smell....like a charity shop, you know? (to constituents) Afternoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of the waiting constituents respond. They go through to another little office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, here you go, you're pretty booked up - there's a list on the desk. I'm just going to have a look at the guttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just back from America, so it was pretty tough to make it up here - but you know. That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Right. How was the President?

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: She's heading off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was the White House like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blown up by spaceships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Miller & Aides up stairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Miller (and an aide or two?) marches into Linton and Karen's section of State. He's got a meeting scheduled. He's a man on a mission. He marches straight past Bob Adriano ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by way of explanation) Twelve-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, hold on General ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And into Linton's office. But - it's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Secretary Linton Barwick wanted me to let you know his last - meeting looks like it's over-running. He sends apologies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller stands there for a beat. Very very annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stood me up? They're better be a fucking good reason. Like he's dead. That is just plain fucking rude. I mean, how would he like it if I just did a big hairy shit on his desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very w-welcome to wait, we have newspapers and periodicals?

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: He gestures to a seating area. Miller picks up a magazine. Rolls it up, looks at Bob Adriano. Might Miller, possibly, hit him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well excuse me if at this time of national crisis I don't sit with a thumb up my ass flipping through Time magazine eating pop tarts? (he heads off fast - not quite sure where he's going, calls back as he goes) Tell him to call me. But he might not get through cos I'm a fucking busy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds himself heading into Karen's office. It's empty. He stands there for a beat. Shuts the door. Looks around. Picks up a hole punch. Kicks the couch. Karen enters, surprised to find him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - can I hang around in here for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er. Sure. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I need a fucking reason? (beat, calming down) Linton's playing me like a fucking turkey drumstick on a big bass drum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I was going to order food, do you want to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Order us some cute mammals. Alive. A lamb or a piglet so I can snap it's fucking neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Simon listens behind a desk. Roz is there taking notes. Toby is in the corner working on a laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point is - if the septic tank - if we didn't know it was there in the first place how can we be responsible for it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's under the communal drive. Why should we get it pumped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking through the paperwork) Well it's not a council sceptic tank so they're not legally obliged to pump it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, according to the paperwork there's four metric tons of of shit under there. That's not all me, is it? I'm not a flipping elephant am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Nor should you be treated like one. Okay, Mrs McDairmid. Leave it with me. I'm sure there must be a way through this. Alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Kendrick heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, Colin Lowe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Still on about bendy buses? (thinks) No. Tell him no. What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby closes the laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline Michaelson's son about the constituency office wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby exits to get coffee as Roz brings in PAUL MICHAELSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he enters) Hi, thanks for seeing me Mr. Foster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Paul, call me Simon. You've met Roz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Simon, I'll try to keep it brief because I can see you're a busy man. There's a bloke out there wants to make it illegal to talk in a foreign language in shops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, this place can become a magnet for the mentally dispossessed. And for sensible people like yourself, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patronising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you explain your issue, Mr Michaelson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...sorry, is this a joke? How many times? For the fourth f...ing time. (as to an idiot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The side wall. Of this property. Your wall. Is falling over. On to my mum's garden. She called you up - but she got fobbed off by your people. Because she's not Lord Snooty in his posh car. Because she's not Madonna on a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...I agree, it's unacceptable. Toby comes back in, hands Simon a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is? (he hums something irritating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your constituency office hold music. I don't want it in my head, do I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did arrange to get a quote from a builder, but... Roz has a call on the landline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patch from London. They say it's urgent. Karen Clark? Is she the coracle woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Paul, I really need to take this, but I haven't forgotten about you, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, well I'm not going anywhere, Simon. You won't be able to forget me because I'll be sitting here staring at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, can I hand Paul over to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Can I fob Paul off with you?" Simon goes elsewhere in the room to take his call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Paul, where are we up to? (off Paul's scary look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was out getting coffee. Sorry. He grabs a pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CHANGE SCENE ORDER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. General Miller is with Karen. They're surrounded by cartons of Chinese take-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flicking through Liza's paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, this is the problem with civilians wanting to go to war. When you've been there you don't want to go back unless you absolutely have to. It's like France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re the paper in it's red folder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finally read Liza's paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course, I read it. I'm a voracious reader. I'm the fucking Gore Vidal of the Pentagon. (pointing at a spring roll)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I want that. (points to various packages) I want that, that, that, that and that. Those I don't care about. And these let's pack up and drop on North Korea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, reads) Someone should leak this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Liza sees them discussing her paper animatedly. It doesn't look good to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone maybe shaped a little bit like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have more gravitas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. I'm too senior. I can't leak. Leaking is for people like your Liza and the Boy called It out there. (eats) It's insane. Not only is the case against war incredibly strong, the case for is caveated to hell. (reading) "Most analysts believe the state is looking to expand aggressively beyond its borders..." Then here in the caveats, the only source is `Ice Man' - a possible alcoholic - who's probably called that cos he gets through ten bags / icebergs a day in his fucking vodka tonics. INR say we can't trust him. That's us disputing our own findings. Has Linton read this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure he reads. You're a General. Have him killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this is why we never got together. That and the hobo teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is talking to Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a private call right -- unrecorded, secure line etc etc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. I mean, your lot are probably getting it somehow, but our lot shouldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Michaelson calls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still here, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on Simon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Departmental business. About a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you in the committee? I called for back-up, you sat there like a dumb sack of shit. Maybe worse, cos at a molecular level a bag of shit is probably fizzing with energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - okay. Yes. Um. Well, I have to say Karen, I have a clear strategy here. I'm playing the long game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no long game. They've bounced us into a short game. You looked like a...what do you call it in England? A 'wanker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't call it that, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby's still talking to Paul the wall guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, look, mate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patronising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. But I'm on your side. I have to look after my Mum too. You do, or they get shafted don't they? So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon wants to talk. Roz takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to pursue this with, what do they call it? Extreme prejudice, to the very end. I can be enormously persistent. Ask my ex-girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well, I'll take your details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roz leads Paul away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy's a bit full-beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full-beam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, full-beam. Headlights. (he opens his eyes wide to show what he means) I kept thinking, is he going to nut me. He appears not to be nutting me, but he might well nut me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did Karen Clark want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I came over as weak on the committee over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, no, of course not. I suppose -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's phone goes again. He winces picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also - the war committee got leaked, and that leak came from your department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find that difficult to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want action to be taken. I want a head. On a plate. To go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the phone) You don't work here. You're not my boss. Fuck off. You can't make me sack people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is getting into his office - he and Toby are back from the constituency office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patronising) I think you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A land line is ringing in the open plan office. Judy picks up. Simon has gone into his office and has assumed the bollocking position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking call) Sorry, this is the wrong extension. I'll put you through now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy punches a button on her phone. Toby's land line starts ringing. Simon comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking backwards into his office) Come, come into my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why do you need to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Judy) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the mad man about the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her out, exasperated) Can you come into my office so I can tell you off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby answers his phone, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sweeps in, straight past Toby, slapping him on the back of the head as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucker. (to phone) No, not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm pushes Judy back into Simon's office as she's leaving it, Simon behind Judy walks backwards to his desk, the three of them in a line. Malcolm shuts the door and unleashes a torrent of abuse we can't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall man Paul is on the phone, standing with a JOURNALIST by the offending wall, now badly propped up. The journalist is taking notes and photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These `temporary buttresses' you got put up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're basically a pair of twigs. Thin twigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they're not twigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No they're twigs. (to Journalist) Are you getting a picture of those twigs? That wall could fall on my mum and crush her. Do you know how old she is? (calling off) Mum, how old are you? I want to tell the newspaper guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this conversation Malcolm arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a word with the minister and Charlotte Fucking Bronte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're never fucking sixty. You're older than that. Sixty. How old are you really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sixty. If it's going in a newspaper, I'm sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off are you sixty. Olivia Newton- John's fucking sixty. And she's not on the statins, is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you tell your mum to stay away from the wall just for the time being?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She needs to get to her plants. (like Toby's an idiot) She has to water them. Plants need water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sure, but could she use a hose, from a distance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't have a hose, she's got a watering can. This is like talking to a brick wall about a brick wall. (to journalist) Get that down, that's gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby can still see Malcolm going ballistic at Simon and Judy in Simon's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen runs out of the lifts. There's even more of a buzz than usual, people running around. She sees Bob Adriano, Linton and Chad in a huddle in Linton's air. Hurries over to Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza, what's up? Why is everyone running around? This better be a fucking fire drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has said he's vetoing tarrifs on Chinese auto imports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Karen calls over to a staffer, ABBEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbey, get me the president's statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Barwick has asked me to... Karen is   beginning to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work to me, Abbey, you fucking work to me. Get me the statement. Or I will call security and have you escorted off the premises via the window. Karen crosses quickly to her office. Liza follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, why is that...? He's...what, buttering the Chinese up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs them to at least abstain in the security council. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the UN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're going to the UN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: Karen kicks a waste-paper basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be told this fucking stuff! I'm going into Linton's office and pulling the pin on his grenade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fucking joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well since I created the budget deficit the President doesn't tend to run things by me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get funny with me. I am not in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm getting that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is with Simon and Toby. Malcolm has a local Northamptonshire paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "While Foster jets around at the taxpayer's expense, his constituency headquarter's wall's collapsing and he doesn't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up paper) No but it says `Wall-ace and Gromitt'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall-ace though?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are being portrayed as the biggest twat in Northamptonshire, and that's going some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is just a wall, Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, my little stem cell, I don't want to be dealing with this either, okay? I've got bigger fucking fish to fry, believe me. I'm rolling blue whales in breadcrumbs at the moment. I'm giving this to Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great. The crossest man in Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie enters, holding another local rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't Humpty-Numpty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, surround bollocking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, I haven't finished. If it isn't Humpty-Numpty, sitting on top of a collapsing wall like some clueless egg- cunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's enough of the fucking Oxbridge pleasantries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is saying "hello" a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing a hole-puncher) Shut it, Love, Actually, or I'll hole- punch your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I'm off to deal with the fate of the planet, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, Toby and Jamie look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that's arrogant. That is just a fucking fact. Don't even look at me. (to Jamie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be gentle with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me, Malcy, kid gloves.   Made from real kids. Malcolm leaves. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Butch and Gaydance, this wall story is playing badly. (looking in his paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, here's a cartoon of you as a walrus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A walrus? I'm not fat. I don't even have a moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look...we hired some builders. They didn't turn up when they said they would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're builders. What did you expect?! Have you ever seen a film where the hero is a builder? No. Because they never turn up in the fucking nick of time.That's why you never see a superhero with a hod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon and Judy on their way into the foreign office. Malcolm has gone in ahead. Suzy chatting on the stairs with Toby. Simon draws Judy to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all getting...this is a really stressful job, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you're not a brain surgeon, you're not a snooker player ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to back a war, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oh this is what it's about) Oh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, drop some hints, put some nods and winks out there, that I'm toying with resignation. Yeah? See if the PM reacts. See how it plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put out some winks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big nods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, just sort of... (he does a small nod) That sort of size nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was just nodding normally to say I understood the need for a small nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a nice room. Malcolm is with Michael, Suzy and a couple of other civil servants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, my lovely friends, bottom line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that phrase. We're not in retailing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Michael, I promise never to use it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottom line, is that the President is going to the UN, and the PM would like us to join him. This will be the voe to commence military action. So, Rob, Innis, (to Toby) Little Bo Cock Jockey (to Judy) And the leaky fucking mingebox, return to your desks and prepare for some extreme briefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two CIVIL SERVANTS get up and exit. Judy walks across the room and starts making calls, as does Toby. Michael walks off into the next room, Suzy follows. They start calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, you still got doubts, Complicated Simon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck, Malcolm. This is all going to spin along from here and we have a vote and we go to war. We fight people, and kill them, and our kids get killed, and that's exactly the sort of thing I didn't want to do when I went into politics. That's the opposite of what I want to be doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you've got to stay in Government. In here you can influence things, delay things. Out there you're just another mad shouty fucker people don't want to make eye-contact with. Remember Mary? She took a stand over Health. Everyone decided she was mental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only because the Sun showed a photo of her with wide eyes and her head on a cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found that a very powerful image. (a beat) Look, the Prime Minister of this country is not a Viking. He doesn't drink blood, he doesn't go round biting tramps. He doesn't go to Chequers at the weekend for a bit of light raping and a pub lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the Prime Minister isn't a Viking, Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike me, the man abhors physical violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a grade A fucking pussy and he knows you have similar concerns and he wants your input on this. Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the intelligence? Where's the hard evidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, We've got evidence harder than a diamond dildo. We have intelligence so deep and hard it would fucking puncture your kidneys.There's an informant, `Ice Man', OK? The stuff he's giving us? It'll make your blood run cold. And clot. Your insides will turn to black pudding. (lowering his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...now, certain box-lickers are sitting on it. But you're going to see it, because the PM regards you as a key player now. Judy's mobile goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy Molloy? (BEAT) Ten minutes. Thanks. (to Simon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prime Minister wants to speak to you in ten minutes, Simon. He want you to go the UN. Malcolm's heading out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See- you're A-list now. You're a Kennedy. In the VIP lounge, with the gold card and the complimentary drinks and the hard-on. Malcolm leaves. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to Malcolm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me the evidence, Malcolm, that's my fucking bottom line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do you still want...nods and winks? Simon nods a little nod. Then shakes his head slightly. Then nods a slight nod again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy, Michael and Judy are having a drink in a pub. Maybe they're sitting in a four seater booth?

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: Their phones are on the table. As is a bottle of Sancerre. Judy's got her power walking trainers on and her rucksack with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers everyone. Here's to surviving another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My theory is Malcolm built Jamie in a lab out of bits of old psychopath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby arrives, dumps his coat, bag, puts his phone on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing the joke again) Hello ladies. I'm just going to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Lovely. I think we could have another bottle of Sancerre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can get served at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the bar. His phone gets a text. Suzy picks it up, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking hell. Here we go again. Fucking arsehole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding? What's it say? (peering at the phone) Woah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzy shows the phone to Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a twat. (beat) What are you doing? Are you replying?

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: Suzy's texting on Toby's mobile. Toby's coming back. Suzy puts the phone back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I wouldn't want to meet Jamie in a dark alley. Or a bright alley. The whole thing of just being in an alley with him would be scary, regardless of the lighting. Suzy cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading, covering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. It's just Rob about football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Liza. You shagged her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Judy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know my flakey boyfriend has been getting his flakey end away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about his flakey end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we not talk about accusations and, health issues, in the pub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't finished your drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mainly have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, it was a weird, intense time over there. It was...maybe, subconsciously, I don't know, it was a kind of last ditch attempt to stop this, awful...war.

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: A beat. Michael and Judy dissolve into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's classic. That's definitely going in the memoirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had sex because of the war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the broad sense. (to Judy and Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, can you stop doing that? Can we go somewhere where they're aren't enormous children eating snacks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I'll go. She goes. Toby goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go. I've got a long walk ahead of me. But that'll keep me going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby lets himself into the flat. Goes through to the kitchen. Suzy is there with Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't actually. (to Michael)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go make that tea. Suzy and Toby go into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I'm leaving, I'm taking my brie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the port. And my Nando's peri-peri sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go back out into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your hydrocortisone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You putting this in your memoirs as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's fine. Stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby is in the bedroom. A few boxes are lying around. He's putting clothes into bin liners. Suzy is hovering. Michael brings through some teas. The atmosphere is very frosty and awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my needlecord jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your geography teacher's jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby thinks better of responding. Starts folding some shirts. Michael takes over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not how you fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, this is one of the more humiliating moments of my life. I can pack a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key to travelling is packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to fucking Fiji Michael, I'm being chucked out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll save time the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby moves through to the kitchen to get his jeans. Suzy and Michael follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she got big tits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Massive. Enormous. You can see them on Google Earth. They've got their own postcode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby gets his jeans and some other clothes. He's laden down with boxes and bags and can hardly see. Comes out into the hall. Suzy is there without Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby struggles to open the front door. Suzy opens it. Toby goes to leave then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Suzy, this is probably going to sound odd under the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. But no. It's about Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good tell me more, tell me more about her tits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Suze, Liza wrote a paper, Pwip- Pip. I think, if it got leaked, it could stop the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the memory stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good tactic. Get earnest. I tried that with the wife. Didn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are such a fucking coward, you know that? And this is what? A make up leak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does such a thing exist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, take your rubbish clothes and your back issues of Mojo, your flute, and your eighth of dope and leave me the fuck alone. Toby leaves the memory stick in the flat. Then heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, Toby and Judy are on the way to Heathrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I resign? I've floated that I might, when I thought I wouldn't, so it'll look convincing if I did. I mean, do you think, is it braver to just resign and say, `No, no war'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is it actually braver to say, `I don't agree, but I'm going to grit my teeth and get on with it?' Is the really brave thing actually doing what you don't believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though -- maybe? What's brave about doing the `right thing'? Nothing. Doing the wrong thing is braver. In a way. I mean, you know, wars sometimes work. The War of Independence, that worked. For the Americans. Second World War. That was a good idea. I mean not a good idea but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. And the Crimean War -- we got nurses out of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurses are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if they've achieved something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. So...right. Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not resigning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I..(trying to change the subject) where's Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, Simon and Toby are walking past a baggage carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially to Toby) In the motorcade. Let's get a car without Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want hookers? You like hooky fucky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk about the resigning thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But with you and not her. She has this air of moral righteousness that inhibits you from... saying anything morally wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon and Toby looking very uptight. Malcolm's with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at phone) So. The wires are all currently reporting that you're going to resign from government over the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? That wasn't supposed to get outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well it is outside. It's lurking outside like a big hairy rapist at a coach station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks to Toby for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know, if I could I'd punch you into total paralysis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 Malcolm, Simon, Toby and Judy are being led through a bleak, soulless basement corridor in the UN by Sir Jonathan Tutt, the British ambassador to the UN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, gentlemen, Sir Jonathan Tutt. This is it. The United Nations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all a bit `blurrrgh', isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could do with a few more scatter cushions and a bit less asbestos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you were expecting -- Jacobean panelling perhaps, arabesques of stonework tracery... great fountains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shithole. It looks like a hospice for robots. They pass a big office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linton Barwick is in there. Karen Clark is there. You're right here. Sir Jonathan shows them to their office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need anything, just whistle. You know how to whistle don't you Malcolm? You just put your lips together and blow. Malcolm and Toby look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I'm off upstairs to the informal delegates' reception. Hope there's nibbles, I'm ravenous. Sir Jonathan leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nibbles? Who still says nibbles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the nibbles, what was with the homoerotic tension? Malcolm gets a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie. Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fucking signal down here. Jesus. I'd be better off in an internet cafe in Kircoddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie is on the phone, running down a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, your phone's off, which means you've been shot dead by a fat American, but there's been a fucktastrophe. Someone's leaked Liza Weld's Pwip Pip paper to the BBC. I reckon it'll be on the Six O'Clock news here, one o'clock your time, so it's going to fist your fucking vote apart. Missing you loads, pwip-pip, toodle-oo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm finishing listening to his voicemail, dialling and running back into the building, pushing past a crowd of smokers at the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Jamie, two jobs. One: find the Pwip Pip leaker and kill them. That's one job. Job one has two parts. Job two: stop Pwip Pip coming out. Sow enough seeds of fear and doubt that the fat arses at the BBC dither till after the vote, okay? After the vote Enola Gay is cleared for take- off and everything is groovy.   I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of delegates drinking and eating and chatting. We glimpse Linton, Karen, General Miller. Sir Jonathan is there, mingling. Malcolm approaches Simon, Toby, Judy and Sir Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sir Jonathan) Do not move from this spot or I'll fucking stab you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simon) Was it you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, what? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know what I'm talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but whatever it was I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Toby) Was it you, The-Baby-From-Eraserhead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Judy) So it must have been you Woman from The Crying Game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't me. You've really got it in for me haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's dropped a bollock in the noodles and I reckon it was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done this all before. You accused me of leaking last time and it wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well I know you didn't leak last time. But what I reckon is you got so pissy about being accused, you leaked this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, that does sound possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Springer Spaniel, keep your little wet nose out alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying psychologically speaking that sounds plausible - that you might build up a resentment and then pay it off in some underhand way. That's just something I've observed. Malcolm's had enough goes over and grabs Sir Jonathan, mid-conversation, and manhandles him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Baldermort, I need a word. Meanwhile Judy and Toby are left alone - Toby embarrassed about his comments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (they look at each other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that - it's just ... (mumbles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: something I've observed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanker. It's okay. It's fine. It's probably just the stress of this awful, awful war. Malcolm drags the ambassador into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a new reality now and You've got to speed things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things? Speed up what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The debate. It needs to start at eleven o'clock, not one thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hehe. Can I perhaps briefly explain the way the process works? And why that isn't possible? You see through that door there are a number of secretariats that are currently doing what we call the washing up now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fucking do it, fishlips. Otherwise you'll find yourself in some medieval warzone in the Caucasus with your arse in the air, trying to persuade a group of men in balaclavas that sustained sexual violence is not the way forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it can't be. I mean it could be done, it just can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll do it. (motioning to a door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're through there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but you can't go in, that would be a serious breach of protocol ... He's blocking Malcolm. Malcolm grabs his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you do it. Get in there. He is almost man-handling him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not dancing with you Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leading, look follow my lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not dancing me into the secretariat! Jonathan breaks off and under his own steam prepares to go in. As Malcolm is leaving Miller blocks his path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the intel? Are you sure you're working as hard as me? Cos I'm sweating spinal fluid here. I'm a husk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get everything you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a hurry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah I think so. Thanks. (a beat, thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Whoa whoa whoa just a wee moment General Flintstone. Was it you? Did you leak Pwip Pip? I know you can't fire a gun, but can you use a fax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, see, because I'm upfront about what I do. I don't creep around like some fucking gay mercenary doing other people's dirty work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing my own work. I'm doing my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-hu. I think you're doing Linton's dirty work. I think you're his English bitch and if I walked into your hotel room tonight I'd find you on all fours in fishnets and him hanging out the back of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo. Tough talk from the armchair General. What you going to do? Throw a cushion at me? Put your feet up on a poof and go back to sleep why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Tucker, you may be some scary poodlefucker back in London, but here? You know what you look like? A fucking squeezed dick. You got a blue vein running all the way up to your temple there. That's where I'd put the fucking bullet. But I'd stand well back. You look like you'd be a squirter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever even killed anybody? Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falling asleep on someone doesn't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done my share. How many you kill, pussy drip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I prefer maiming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, tough guy, take a swing at me. I'll smack you so fucking hard you'll be shitting teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I can see the headlines now. 'Peace-Loving General Starts Fight In UN, Swiss Intervene'. I don't know, I'm no expert on spin but could that hurt your career?

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: They eyeball each other. Is Miller going to hit him? He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Do excuse me. I've got work to do. Oh, and don't EVER call me fucking English again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Jonathan walks in. A lot of faces are turned towards him, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello everyone. I was wondering if I might suggest a cheeky early vote? Bit of an adventure. Maybe, we could knock off early, go for a drink? Ha. I'm kidding. Or am I? No, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen and Miller are looking at a computer screen, presumably reading about Simon's floated resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at computer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is. Simon's going. Everyone's saying he's going. Simon passes their open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spotting Simon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon! There he is! Simon. (re internet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great shit. I wasn't sure you had the nerve. You're resigning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah okay. They're not running with that? I have not said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not resigning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still playing the hawk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's much subtler than that. It's nuanced. I'm playing a much cleverer game than that. I'm a (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fake hawk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Fake hawk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fake hawk? You're a fucking idiot. You're not a fake idiot are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen and Miller go into a confab. Karen and Miller immediately go into a huddle and start planning Simon's future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to General Miller, as if Simon's not there) We could just tell the press he's going anyway. Say he's confirmed to us that he's resigning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I second that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we announce it before or after the vote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During. Then he can't do anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. That's decided then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No it's bloody not. I'm - me. You're not me. I decide about all the main things about me, okay? Not you. Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No Simon. I'm afraid not. Not on this one. This is too big for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be realistic. You're being used. We all are. The one thing we can do now to influence things is to resign. Sacrifice ourselves. That's our only weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a suicide bomber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not like a suicide bomber. A suicide bomber gets to make a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby and Liza are sitting near each other on the floor working on laptops. They're at right-angles to each other. Toby has a view of Liza. She's facing away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm really sorry about Suzy and the texting and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Thanks. Do you have figures there for CFE minimum requirements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conventional Forces in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I'll just dig that out. (beat, taps on his laptop, then very quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it was a very special evening for me and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? What? You're mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wandered if tonight when all this shit is over we couldn't - you know. You're single. I'm single now. You're a woman. I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to have sex again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a terrible idea is it? One more. For the Gipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a douchbag is Toby? You're a douchbag on fucking wheels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. That was short and sweet. Well, short and sour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is sitting in the Meditation Room, a stark chapel- like room with a big piece of granite in the middle of it. He's biting his nails, thinking. Judy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of becoming a suicide bomber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's certainly a very powerful way of getting your point across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out some mints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a mint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay thanks. Are you thinking to overdose on mints? Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon eats a mint. He's lost in his own world. Staring, maybe slightly nodding at the thoughts in his own head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like me Judy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but do you actually like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Look, I'll leave you to your thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got any thoughts. I'm just staring vacantly into space while a distant voice in the back of my head goes "oh shit" like a car alarm in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon eats another mint. Sits there noisily sucking it. Judy leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Suzy are sitting talking in an FO office. Jamie bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you. I know it wasn't you, you're too fucking horny for your Knighthood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was what me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it fucking you!? Answer the question!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't very well answer the question if you don't tell her what it is, can she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off to your room, Count of Cunty Cristo, this is between me and her. (to Suzy) You leaked Liza Weld's paper to the BBC. Tell me you leaked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't leak anything. I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying. You touched your nose. That's what's called a `tell'. You are lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `No I'm not.' That's a tell as well. Classic. (changing tack to terror) I know the leak came from here, from this fucking fax machine here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes a fax casually off the table onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what I'm doing to the machine. (he kicks it, hard till bits start to break off, but he's still quite controlled talking, as he kicks more) You see? This is how angry I am with the piece of office equipment which leaked this document, so can you imagine how angry I am with the person who did it? Yeah? Can you Suzy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kicks the fax machine again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck off. Don't come over all Spartacus now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leaked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
